creepy and loud beat that is joined by chainsaw guitars.The lyrics also dark and great. <br /> <br />Every Day Is Exactly the Same <br /> <br />my favorite song on the cd,and one of my all time favorite NIN songs.Not only because I relate to the lyrics about isolation and tiring of life's daily routines so much.But also because the music is so anthemic and catchy, and the chorus so addictively memorable \\"Everyday exactly the same/There is no love here and there is no pain\\".)The part when he sings \\"I cant remember how this got started,but I can tell you exactly how this will end\\" gives me chills. <br /> <br />With Teeth <br /> <br />reminds me a little of \\"Reptile'.Very strange but has a nice <br />memorable chorus. <br /> <br />Only <br /> <br />my second most favorite track.Anyone who grew up in the 80's will love the odd retro synths and drums.And especially the playful spoken word.The words seem to be about battling one's self-made demons. <br /> <br />Getting Smaller <br /> <br />after the two odd but great tracks,its back to more brutal but very catchy and anthemic industrial rock.The \\"Flip Flop Flip\\" lyric in the beginning might be a clue as to what Trent is raging <br />against. <br /> <br />Sunspots <br /> <br />Pure Pretty Hate Machine era NIN! <br /> <br /> <br />The Line Begins to Blur <br /> <br />pure anger in the verse gives way to sadness in the chorus. <br />\\" I always knew what side to be on.Now i'm not so sure. <br />The Line begins to blur\\". <br /> <br />Beside You In Time  <br /> <br />reminds me of \\"Something I Can Never Have\\" but without the keyboards.Very pretty. <br /> <br />Right Where It Belongs  <br /> <br />in the tradition of sad NIN closers,Right Where It Belongs is a really sad lullabye-suicidal ballad of hopelessness and depression.The lonely keyboard,the haunting atmospherics and Trent's voice filled with pain. \\"what if the whole world is inside your head,just creations of your own,the devils and the gods,the living and the dead,and you are really all alone.You can live in this illusion,you can chose to believe.you keep looking but you cant find the words,now your hiding in a dream...if you look at your reflections are you all you wanted to be?\\".If you love \\"Hurt\\" then you will love this. <br /> <br />again,With Teeth is an amazing heartfelt,powerful album.The problem with an \\"alternative\\" band having a big hit is that people who will never \\"get it\\" start jumping on the bandwagon <br />but they are too low level in intelegents to actually \\"get it\\". <br />Thous people would be better served by the new Limp Bizkit cd.For which thinking is not required!
B0007O38XU|3.0|The movie itself is pure Mel Brooks. I really enjoy how Mel brings hilarious havoc to the sci-fi genre, spoofing movies from Flash Gordon and Buck Rogers to Star Trek and Star Wars.  I am surprised that MPAA had originally given this movie a PG rating instead of a PG-13 rating since the movie is heavy on adult humor, language, and sexual innuendos - not exactly what I would call a flick for the whole family.  Enough about the movie; this review is about the newly released Collector's Edition (CE), especially the bonus material.<br /><br />The Dolby 5.1 sound quality has been enhanced compared to the original 2000 DVD release, but I will need to confirm this.  I'm glad MGM offers a DTS track on disc 1.  I have not yet compared Mel's commentary on the CE to the original release.  I did make some limited comparisons of the picture quality: The colors are more vibrant (perhaps too much on the red?) and the picture is clearer to my eyes; the skin tones look correct to me. Since the video presentation is not THX quality, you will see some specks and film blemishes. The aspect ratio on the CE (1.85:1 for 16x9) is the same as the original 2000 release, but on my Sony monitor (4:3) the CE widescreen version is \\"slightly\\" zoomed in more than the 2000 widescreen released version.<br /><br />I am disappointed in the Special Features. Why? For one reason, it does not include Rick Moranis.  He is mentioned but is not interviewed at all - how can Mel not include Dark Helmet!  In addition, you will not find any behind-the-scenes coverage (other than still photos) such as those found on the 2000 DVD release. Mel did not include any deleted scenes or bloopers (no, the film flubs don't count).  However, there is a well-produced 29 minute documentary that includes the other main actors and crew members. You will learn that the actors and crew members had more laughs making this movie than the audience had watching it.  If this is true, Mel should have included some of those comical moments in the Special Features.  Also missing on this CE is a featurette about special-effects.  The conversation between Mel and co-writer Thomas Meehan is rather boring, but the tribute to comical genius John Candy is commendable, touching, and about time.<br /><br />The CE is a 2-disc DVD set.  It is a shame that MGM and Mel could not/would not include more about this classic comedy.  Overall I give the CE version a 3/5. The movie gets 4/5!ial Features. The conversation between Mel and co-writer Thomas Meehan is rather boring, but the tribute to comical genius John Candy is commendable, touching, and about time.    The CE is a 2-disc DVD set.  It is a shame that MGM and Mel could not/would not include more about this classic comedy.  Overall I give the CE version a 3/5. The movie gets 4/5!
B0007TKNL0|5.0|I have been a huge fan of this musical for close to twenty years.  I used to tell people that I felt sorry for anyone whose first theatre experience was \\"Phantom\\" because nothing else could ever measure up to its opulence and grandeur, and other great works would suffer by comparison.      I had high hopes for the movie, and although I enjoyed it immensely, deep down I felt that the vocal performances of the three leads left just a little to be desired.  Nevertheless, the film was stunning with its lush production values, and as I sat in the theatre, I knew I was just exactly where I wanted to be.  It was great to really see the expressions on the faces of the actors, and just that luxury alone made the movie a whole new worthwhile \\"Phantom\\" experience.    I received my DVD today, and looked at the extras first.  They were enormously entertaining, and worth the price of the DVD by themselves.  Then, I started to watch the feature, but, on a whim, turned on the French audio track.  I had never heard \\"Phantom\\" in French before, but since the setting of the piece is Paris, I thought French might add a flair of authenticity to this wonderful romantic tale.  I was blown away...just who are these French and/or French Canadian actors/singers who did the dubbing for this DVD release???  I wish they were credited.      The French musicals \\"Notre Dame de Paris,\\" \\"Romeo et Juliette,\\" and \\"Autant En Emporte Le Vent,\\" along with many others, owe their very existence to Andrew Lloyd Webber and his theatrical visions.  Now, \\"Phantom\\" may be the greatest French musical of them all..these performances are chilling.    It was terrific to once again experience \\"Phantom Of The Opera\\" in yet a third and even more brilliant light.
B000929AJQ|4.0|Im sick of hearing people whine about this album not sounding like the Downward Spiral - anyone who's listened to all of Reznor's previous albums would realize that you have to respect none of them have yet to sound alike.  He cant have that teen angst/aggression sound forever, and for people to dismiss a new work of art because its not the same as your favorite makes for a very closed minded individual.  Im thankful that we at least still have an artist around who doesnt want regurgitate what somebody else wrote and dance around on a stage because that's what their record label tells them to do - this is not the definition of a musician, its the definition of a puppet. <br /> <br />Now that ive said my piece...on to the review...   <br /> <br />I feel this album could have slid in nicely after Pretty Hate Machine era in terms of sound...it has a lot of synth pop mixed with some of the elements of the Broken EP.  A true NIN fan will enjoy this as it is Trent doing what he does best - demonstrating emotion through his music.  Only difference is this time around you get to hear it in his words more so than the music - a welcomed change for me as I dont always want to hear the sonic intensity of the spiral (even though I love that album, too).  I have enjoyed watching Reznor grow as an artist and am happy to add this one to the collection.  While I realize NIN isnt everyone's cup of tea (and I wouldnt recommend it to just anyone) I just want to point out that you can always buy it, try it out, and if you hate it, take it to a used cd store for a credit.  If youve liked the past albums and arent put off to him evolving, you will like this.   <br /> <br />Happy Listening, <br />Azure
B000002U82|5.0|It's no mystery why 'Dark Side of The Moon' has remained on the charts for so long: it's great music.  This is not the greatest album of all time or even Pink Floyd's greatest album, however.  It's not even that accessible.  When I first got it, I remember I only really liked the song \\"Money\\" and the rest was kind of strange.  \\"Why do they wait so long to start singing?  and what's with the clashing synthesizers?\\" I thought.  The truth is that most people buy this CD because they've heard _of_ it, or because their friend told them it was great.  To hear this CD once, and then be in love with it is something that's not possible unless you're a big fan of the band, and in which case you should already have this.  Why am I talking about all this?  To give a little perspective.  Although it's commonly placed under the now vague subheading of ROCK/POP in music stores, don't expect a rock record or a pop record.  The songs \\"Money\\" and \\"Time\\" are rock songs to be sure, but this music it far wider in its scope and far grander in its effects than your run of the mill rock record.  One must have an open mind to appreciate 'Dark Side of The Moon.'  Like I said earlier, you can't have a fixed idea of when they should start singing, or how long is too long for a vocal solo.  To even start to appreciate this CD, you need to forget everything you ever knew about music, just sit back, and relax.  It's a great record. <br /> <br />If you like this, you might also like: <br />Animals - Pink Floyd <br />Wish You Were Here - Pink Floyd <br />The Wall - Pink Floyd <br />Meddle - Pink Floyd <br />To Our Children's Children's Children - The Moody Blues <br />A Passion Play - Jethro Tull <br />In The Court of The Crimson King - King Crimson <br />Demons and Wizards - Uriah Heep
B0008ISM40|5.0|Nine Inch Nails are back with their fourth effort \\"With Teeth,\\" and once again Trent Reznor has made an outstanding album.<br /><br />Although the album has a sense of urgency, \\"With Teeth\\" is not as angry or intense as \\"Pretty Hate Machine,\\" (1989) or \\"The Downward Spiral\\" (1994). Overall, I think the actual songs on \\"With Teeth\\" sound most similar to those on \\"The Fragile\\" (1999). Unlike \\"The Fragile,\\" however, there are not any instrumentals. \\"With Teeth\\" gets more to-the-point. Although I personally loved the long instrumentals on \\"The Fragile,\\" fans who thought the album was too self-indulgent or long, may be more pleased with the format of \\"With Teeth.\\"<br /><br />One additional difference between \\"The Fragile\\" and \\"With Teeth\\" is the welcome addition of drummer Dave Grohl on several of the tracks. His playing gives the album more of a live, organic feel, and gives the sound a shot in the arm. Unfortunately, what tracks he plays on are not listed on the CD case and there is no booklet. However, you'll know when you hear him.<br /><br />I liked \\"With Teeth\\" after the first listen. However, much like \\"The Fragile\\" this is definitely an album that grows on you with repeated plays. There's a lot going on in all of the songs-subtle things, solos, guitars and keyboards-things that you might not pick up on the first couple times. It definitely gets better with repeated plays. Like all Nine Inch Nails albums, each song is meticulously and painstakingly crafted, there is no filler.<br /><br />The themes of \\"With Teeth\\" are similar to those on past NIN albums-loneliness, rage, fear, nihilism-but Reznor sounds less bleak, more confident, if only slightly so.<br /><br />The album starts out with the rather sluggish \\"All the Love in the World,\\" which has an almost claustrophobic feel. It sort of grinds itself along, and gives way to a satisfying buildup and  sublime finale when the piano kicks in towards the end.<br /><br />\\"You Know What You Are?\\" sounds frantic, and is intensified by the pounding drums.<br /><br />\\"The Collector\\" has a really cool, almost funky bass line. It has a great groove and the chorus is really melodic. It's very infectious.<br /><br />\\"The Hand that Feeds\\" was a good pick as the first single, as it is pretty representative of the album as a whole. This mid-tempo industrial rocker is very catchy.<br /><br />The slow-paced \\"Love is Not Enough\\" is one of the album's more rock orientated songs, when the guitars kick in. The verse sort of rolls along, and then explodes into the chorus. The keyboard solo toward the end is a nice touch.<br /><br />I think \\"Everyday is Exactly the Same\\" would be a good choice for the next single. It has a very cool, low-key industrial background. It reminds me somewhat of \\"That's What I Get\\" from \\"Pretty Hate Machine.\\" The song is especially beautiful when the piano kicks in.<br /><br />The album's title track \\"With Teeth\\" takes a few listens to get into. It starts out rather sluggish and claustrophobic...and then...you can hardly hear anything, as Trent Reznor whispers the words over a faint piano...it's very melancholy...and then it gets back to where it started, only now it is more intense.<br /><br />\\"Only\\" has a bit of retro feel; it sort of sounds like something Gary Numan or Devo might do. It has a lot of synths going on and is very interesting. It's really catchy and I think a potential single.<br /><br />The fast paced \\"Getting Smaller\\" is effective and keeps up the momentum.<br /><br />The pacing of \\"Sunspots\\" is what makes the song really work. It starts out slow, builds up, intensifies, slows down again, builds up, intensifies, it keeps the listener intrigued. The keyboards and guitars are subtly added in and sort of creep up on you-it's a cool effect.<br /><br />The distorted \\"The Line Begins to Blur\\" is mid-paced, but intense. It transforms and becomes hauntingly melodic. The guitar solo, while not technically brilliant, is really catchy and part of the song's highlight.<br /><br />\\"Beside You in Time\\" keeps going on-and-off, like when you turn a radio off-and-on-this creates a really cool throbbing effect. The song actually sounds like it's throbbing. The throbbing gets more and more intense as the song rolls along.<br /><br />The closing \\"Right Where it Belongs\\" is beautifully eerie. The piano and the underwhelming vocals really give the song a nice effect. The song builds up and gets more intense; but the song, and the album, go out with a whimper rather than a bang (not that that's a bad thing).<br /><br />Again, this album takes a few listens to really appreciate. It gets better and better with successive plays. \\"With Teeth\\" is an album to be relished with repeated listens.<br /><br />If you've never liked Nine Inch Nails, this album probably won't win you over. If you disliked \\"The Fragile,\\" you also probably won't like this album. If you disliked \\"The Fragile\\" because of its long instrumentals, but liked the actual songs, you will probably like this to. Most NIN fans in general should be pleased with \\"With Teeth.\\"really cool throbbing effect. The song actually sounds like it's throbbing. The throbbing gets more and more intense as the song rolls along.     The closing \\"Right Where it Belongs\\" is beautifully eerie. The piano and the underwhelming vocals really give the song a nice effect. The song builds up and gets more intense; but the song, and the album, go out with a whimper rather than a bang (not that that's a bad thing).     Again, this album takes a few listens to really appreciate. It gets better and better with successive plays. \\"With Teeth\\" is an album to be relished with repeated listens.     If you've never liked Nine Inch Nails, this album probably won't win you over. If you disliked \\"The Fragile,\\" you also probably won't like this album. If you disliked \\"The Fragile\\" because of its long instrumentals, but liked the actual songs, you will probably like this to. Most NIN fans in general should be pleased with \\"With Teeth.\\"

Also, are we to think that Kevin Spacey's character WOULD have had sex with an underage girl had he NOT found out she was a virgin???  This point is completely ignored and, upon reflection, takes some of the movie's luster away.  However, I found the movie to be great nonetheless.  So much of it rang true, even amongst the cliches, that it made a lasting impression. There's a lot going on in all of the songs-subtle things, solos, guitars and keyboards-things that you might not pick up on the first couple times. It definitely gets better with repeated plays. Like all Nine Inch Nails albums, each song is meticulously and painstakingly crafted, there is no filler.<br /><br />The themes of \\"With Teeth\\" are similar to those on past NIN albums-loneliness, rage, fear, nihilism-but Reznor sounds less bleak, more confident, if only slightly so.<br /><br />The album starts out with the rather sluggish \\"All the Love in the World,\\" which has an almost claustrophobic feel. It sort of grinds itself along, and gives way to a satisfying buildup and  sublime finale when the piano kicks in towards the end.<br /><br />\\"You Know What You Are?\\" sounds frantic, and is intensified by the pounding drums.<br /><br />\\"The Collector\\" has a really cool, almost funky bass line. It has a great groove and the chorus is really melodic. It's very infectious.<br /><br />\\"The Hand that Feeds\\" was a good pick as the first single, as it is pretty representative of the album as a whole. This mid-tempo industrial rocker is very catchy.<br /><br />The slow-paced \\"Love is Not Enough\\" is one of the album's more rock orientated songs, when the guitars kick in. The verse sort of rolls along, and then explodes into the chorus. The keyboard solo toward the end is a nice touch.<br /><br />I think \\"Everyday is Exactly the Same\\" would be a good choice for the next single. It has a very cool, low-key industrial background. It reminds me somewhat of \\"That's What I Get\\" from \\"Pretty Hate Machine.\\" The song is especially beautiful when the piano kicks in.<br /><br />The album's title track \\"With Teeth\\" takes a few listens to get into. It starts out rather sluggish and claustrophobic...and then...you can hardly hear anything, as Trent Reznor whispers the words over a faint piano...it's very melancholy...and then it gets back to where it started, only now it is more intense.<br /><br />\\"Only\\" has a bit of retro feel; it sort of sounds like something Gary Numan or Devo might do. It has a lot of synths going on and is very interesting. It's really catchy and I think a potential single.<br /><br />The fast paced \\"Getting Smaller\\" is effective and keeps up the momentum.<br /><br />The pacing of \\"Sunspots\\" is what makes the song really work. It starts out slow, builds up, intensifies, slows down again, builds up, intensifies, it keeps the listener intrigued. The keyboards and guitars are subtly added in and sort of creep up on you-it's a cool effect.<br /><br />The distorted \\"The Line Begins to Blur\\" is mid-paced, but intense. It transforms and becomes hauntingly melodic. The guitar solo, while not technically brilliant, is really catchy and part of the song's highlight.<br /><br />\\"Beside You in Time\\" keeps going on-and-off, like when you turn a radio off-and-on-this creates a really cool throbbing effect. The song actually sounds like it's throbbing. The throbbing gets more and more intense as the song rolls along.<br /><br />The closing \\"Right Where it Belongs\\" is beautifully eerie. The piano and the underwhelming vocals really give the song a nice effect. The song builds up and gets more intense; but the song, and the album, go out with a whimper rather than a bang (not that that's a bad thing).<br /><br />Again, this album takes a few listens to really appreciate. It gets better and better with successive plays. \\"With Teeth\\" is an album to be relished with repeated listens.<br /><br />If you've never liked Nine Inch Nails, this album probably won't win you over. If you disliked \\"The Fragile,\\" you also probably won't like this album. If you disliked \\"The Fragile\\" because of its long instrumentals, but liked the actual songs, you will probably like this to. Most NIN fans in general should be pleased with \\"With Teeth.\\"a really cool throbbing effect. The song actually sounds like it's throbbing. The throbbing gets more and more intense as the song rolls along.     The closing \\"Right Where it Belongs\\" is beautifully eerie. The piano and the underwhelming vocals really give the song a nice effect. The song builds up and gets more intense; but the song, and the album, go out with a whimper rather than a bang (not that that's a bad thing).     Again, this album takes a few listens to really appreciate. It gets better and better with successive plays. \\"With Teeth\\" is an album to be relished with repeated listens.     If you've never liked Nine Inch Nails, this album probably won't win you over. If you disliked \\"The Fragile,\\" you also probably won't like this album. If you disliked \\"The Fragile\\" because of its long instrumentals, but liked the actual songs, you will probably like this to. Most NIN fans in general should be pleased with \\"With Teeth.\\"
B000929AJQ|4.0|When I first put the record in and heard the jazzy and smooth All The Love In The World, I was stoked. After listening to 6 songs, I was livid with rage. \\"What is this crap?\\" I was asking myself. Trent, you have 7 more songs to redeem yourself, I thought. Well, there weren't any brilliant flashes and aside from The Line Begins to Blur I wasn't hearing the texture I was so desperately seeking. By this time I was screaming at the computer and looking at my receipt to find a return policy. But  I managed to somehow gather my wits, and I started it back on track one with a new attitude. As I was pleased to find, the texture was there, it was just so refined that it had lost that choppy, cold and mechanicalness. We had moved from \\"industrial\\" to electro noise pop. I started to smile, looking past the typical reznor lyrics to the warmth of this album, then it hit me. This is probably the most rock and roll piece of work the man has ever done. It's probably the second funkiest, possibly tied with Pretty Hate Machine. This album REQUIRES repeated play to take it in, especially for the hardcore Broken NIN fans. Give it a chance and just relax, it's not that it's gone soft, it's just that it's now found SOUL. It's practicly Motown.
0743454537|5.0|What a storyline...a child conceived to save the life of a sibling.  It hooked me, then Picoult's style reeled me in.   When she described how and when Kate was diagnosed with cancer, my heard just ached.  It's been a long time since a book actually made me cry as I read, but this one did it.  Her description of the chemo and other medical treatments and procedures made me think she has to have lived through this in order to be so detailed.  The chapters are told in first person point of view, but the author switches between characters.  So, one chapter will be told from the mother's point of view, the next from the daughter, the next from the father, or the brother, etc.  I enjoy getting to know all of the characters so intimately. I will certainly search out other books by Picoult.  My Sister's Keeper has deeply affected me...and it has reminded me to be thankful for my healthy children.

B0008ISM40|5.0|Picking up where Reznor left off, where real music lies, this album proves no less. Reznor doesn't disappoint as he touches on all emphases of sound.  While WITH_TEETH is straight to the point with little time to spare the only downfall is the lack of instrumentals and synth sounds we are all used to. However, I wouldn't have this album any other way, and it was worth the six year wait.

B0008ISM40|2.0|My impression of this album after listening and relistening to the songs over the past several weeks has been one of blank disappointment. Trent has been my favourite artist for a few years now and I had been awaiting this album religiously. The end result however, has been very depressing. <br /> <br />The album begins rather well with the honest, introspective monologue at the beginning of All the Love in the World. Upon hearing this I was drawn in and had high expectations. It doesn't take long before the album heads downhill, however. After the first couple of minutes, the song heads into a drawn out repitition of the chorus (and it's a very poor chorus). It could have been redeemed from this grey area, but instead Trent heads off into a lighthearted, high-pitched chant of the chorus that sounds like it would be better suited for a lame feel-good movie, rather than the latest NIN album. As traumatic as the ending of All the Love in the World is, I was able to shrug it off and move on to the next track. <br /> <br />Unfortunately, tracks 2-5 are all skippable, monotonous trash. We begin with You Know What You Are. The majority of the track is dominated by Trent's Donald Duck-like altered voice screaming \\"DON'T YOU F***ING KNOW WHAT YOU ARE?\\" No Trent, I don't, why don't you tell me? He doesn't provide us with an answer however. Other than a slightly interesting interlude, the song is musically irritating, and the rhetorical nature of the lyrics just leaves the listener scratching their head. Next is The Collector, which I believe may in fact be the most bland rock song I've heard in my entire life. The lyrics seem to be some kind of metaphor about carrying around feelings (perhaps bad ones), but it doesn't make a whole lot of sense to me. Either way, the song itself is so poor that I wouldn't even want to listen to it if the lyrics were incredible. Like pouring raw sewage on an open wound, it leads right into The Hand That Feeds. Just when you thought the music couldn't get anymore plain and and uninventive... I'll save myself the trouble of even describing this track, because if you've heard it then you should have an idea of what I'm talking about (crappy U2 leftovers anyone?). Love Is Not Enough comes next. What can I say about this track? The tempo is pretty dull; it just sort of drags on slowly without anything interesting. The lyrics sound worthy of Nickleback. Next! <br /> <br />Every Day is Exactly the Same starts out really well. After the preceding pile of crap, the beginning of this song sounds like a musical oasis. Unfortunately, it takes a turn for the worst after the chorus kicks in. One thing that I've noticed about this album is that some of the chrouses just don't fit very well. This song epitomizes this problem, as we go from a brooding industrial tempo to an Elton John piano chant. The chorus isn't *that* bad, but it just doesn't do the song justice and the result is that it doesn't have a very good flow. In spite of its lackluster nature, this song is perhaps my favourite on the album--and trust me, that says more about the rest of the album than about this song, because this song still isn't very good... <br /> <br />Next is With Teeth. Either it's about a drug addiction or him having a hard-on for some girl; I sure can't tell, and either way I can't relate very much. Musically, the song is another boring one. It drags on monotonously with him repeatedly shouting A-WITH-A-TEETH-A, and the interlude (like many, many other aspects of the album) is terribly underproduced and comes across a bit too quiet and muffled. <br /> <br />Then we have Only. Admittedly, I thought it was pretty cool the first time I heard it, but it's so dancey and the second verse (re: Down In It) is so lame and juvenile that it just began to annoy me after a number of listens. I can see why it was chosen as the second single. It's hardly a classic NIN track though. <br /> <br />Err Getting Smaller... you heard it here first, folks:he's got his arms in flip flop. Kill me now. This track is so obnoxious (and reminiscent of Foo Fighters or Queens of the Stone Age) that I can hardly stand it. I suppose this is a groundbreaking track, because although there's been some NIN songs where I can't necessarily relate to what he's saying, this may in fact be the first scenario in which I completely *disagree* with what he's saying. There's \\"some great thing that we could achieve\\"? What the hell is that supposed to mean? For the sake of the review I'll stop my antagonistic babbling and just reiterate that this is a terribly obnxious song with piss por lyrics. <br /> <br />There's only so much complaining that I can do at once, and at this point I've already tired myself out, so I'll have to try and keep the rest short.  <br /> <br />Sunspots: Better than the majority of the album (again, this is not saying much), but the chorus sounds like a really bad Fine Young Cannibals song. His \\"nothing can stop my now\\" reference seems a little lame, but whatever floats your boat... <br /> <br />The Line Begins to Blur: Sounds pretty good. It's certainly not a great song in terms of his former standards, but I have no complaints other than the theme of succumbing to jadedness being pretty uninspiring. <br /> <br />Beside You In Time: It's alright. Sort of a monotonous interlude style track, but the ending is kind of cool. <br /> <br />Right Where it Belongs: Some people love it. I think it's a cheesy ending with a lot of rhetorical, dreamy lyrics that go nowhere. (Not that I have anything against lyrics having a dreamy quality--I actually enjoy it sometimes--but in this case you get the feeling that he's trying to convey some kind of life lesson to the listener that even he doesn't know). To top this off, it's very, very underproduced and the song is essentially drowned in fuzz until the last chorus when his voice rises in a quick and unrealistic fashion. <br /> <br />So that's my take on the album. I've given it 2 stars, as I think it could have been worse, but more importantly, it could have--and should have--been much, much better. All this album has really done is taught me that I'm not always going to like Trent's music, which is a hard lesson learned, but I figured I was going to have to learn it sooner or later. <br />

B000929AJQ|5.0|Every NIN album has a different mood.  Pretty Hate Machine was Trent's big hello.  Downward spiral was a dark, sad, twisted dive into oblivion, and to this day remains a classic album.  The Fragile is a very mysterious epic opus, in which it needs to be listened to all the way through, definatly one of MY personal favs period.  With Teeth is a different animal altogether.  Gone is the sadness, gone is the darkness.  This album focuses on the ups and downs of love, and it shows through his tracks.  Lets face it, Trent is probably close to 40 years old by now.  How many years can he do the same old song and dance?  His music reflects what he's going through in his life.  First he was angry, then he was sad, then he was enigmatic...Now he's in Love.  I'm a huge NIN fan and always have been, and I believe this is a great way to introduce his music to younger fans, who will then go deeper into his library.  And for us lifelong fans, hey, it's more NIN, and thats always a good thing.  People here can say he's gone soft, or its new wave anger-rock...whatever.  Trent still knows how to make an awesome rock song, and put a little darkness in it.  This album is a breath of fresh air considering all the CRAP out there right now.  Rock has become glam again with turd like good charlotte and My chemical romance...NIN puts BALLS out there.  He's the Man until somebody proves to be better, and almost 20 years after Hate Machine...nobody's better.

B0007YMUZW|5.0|I am not a music expert, or a critic, just a regular person who loves music but gets bummed when I shell out for an album and it ends up that I don't like most of it, and I'm disappointed. I saw an interview Ryan did on Much Music and he said \\"I know I'm not the greatest song writer in the world and I'm never going to be- but I really love doing it, and it doesn't hurt anybody\\".  After this, I could argue many he is one of the great ones!  I hope everyone who buys this album enjoys it as much as me. Thank you for reading this.
B00005B58Y|5.0|Don't get me wrong, Bill Evans and Jimmy Cobb are great musicians and I am a fan of both, but to me The Miles Davis Quintet, and later Sextet were most inspired when Red Garland on piano and Philly Joe Jones on drums were along with Miles on trumpet, John Coltrane on tenor, Cannonball Adderly on alto, and Paul Chambers on bass.  <br /> <br />Red Garland left during the recording of this album, and Philly Joe Jones was let go short there after, making this 1958 date, the last great Davis Sextet album.  <br /> <br />As usual Miles is running through a mix  of popular and jazz standards. The album opens up with one of the sickest tunes by altoist Jackie Mclean. Dr Jackle, not Jeckle is up-tempo, fast, furious and grooving. Miles's solos at high speeds were always great. Listening to his phrasing. It's wonderful. Especially when Miles and Philly Joe are trading solos, the tune is really hot. <br /> <br />The next piece, Sid's Ahead is a 12 minute medium tempo blues piece. Some nice improvisations all around. The tune that Philly Joe was showcased on, the year before, on Sonny Clark's Trio album, is here also. A John Lewis original, Two Bass Hit, is any drummer's ideal suite.  <br /> <br />The title track, Milestones has become a jazz classic. Note Philly Joe's cross-stick pattern, and as it changes during the bridge.  <br /> <br />Ah, the greatest trio cut in the history of jazz. Red Garland, Paul Chambers and Philly Joe Jones do, Billy Boy. Garland used to love this piece. He did it on several of his trio albums. The three do it here well. One of my favorite trio cuts my ears have heard. <br /> <br />The album ends with Monk's classic Straight No Chaser. It swings, not one of my favorite verions, but its Miles. What else can you say. <br /> <br />Obviously the sextet recorded Kind Of Blue which is arguably the greatest jazz album of all time, but as far as a group effort, Milestones wins hands down. Unlike the Quintet albums, (the last four albums for Prestige) his Columbia cuts were more polished. This album is a classic. Any young generation kid or someone just getting into jazz should start within the lines of this disk. <br /> <br />Legendary..
B00000K0DT|5.0|This is a thriller with a twist. I've always liked movies that leave you in the dark until the last possible moment and this movie is a prime example.     Kevin Spacey stars in this deceptive film about five high-ranking conmen and their last major job before they are all killed in an attempt to blow up a boat with an inordinate amount of cocaine. The payoff: $91 million. To the dismay (or demise i should say) of the five \\"usual suspects\\" the objective doesn't seem to be there. But somehow the money is.     Anyone who likes this kind of convoluted suspense will definitely appreciate this flick. It really makes you realize how smart and shady the filmmakers are in the sense that they show you that the audiences' expectations can really be used against them. After watching this movie you will constantly be thinking the name Kaiser Soze and how you can't trust cripples anymore.

B0007ZEO4G|5.0|First of all, this review is based on the assumption that this US edition is from the very same master as the version that recently came out in the UK.   <br /> <br />'Burn' is my all-time favorite album - it went a very long way towards shaping my own drumming style and overall musical tastes.  Previous CD issues of this album were lack-luster at best, with distracting amounts of hiss and digital graininess.  As many times as I've listened closely to the album and old CDs, I am now able to hear things very clearly that I've never noticed before. <br /> <br />I always thought a good way to describe this music is 'blues from the future'.  There's something very special about this particular blend of Blackmore's funky playing with Jon Lord's swirling organ and David Coverdale's and Glenn Hughes' excellent vocals.  Ian Paice nearly steals the show, however, with his blazing drumming throughout.  The extensive liner notes on the UK import edition provided interesting insight into some of the reasons for the extra-aggressive drums on the title track.  I'm not sure whether this US edition includes the same liner notes.   <br /> <br />Highly recommended for anyone who loves hard rock played with authority, dexterity, and taste.
B000929AJQ|5.0|Song by song review. <br /> <br />1.- All the love in the world - A slow song that sets the mood but in a quite slow way. At first it seems like a forgettable song but it develops into a very solid rock tune mixing distorted guitars and piano while Trent, in his singular voice, ask \\"Why you get all the love in the world?\\" <br /> <br />2.- You know what you are? - A fast, action filled song that reminds us of Starf*ckers or the Pretty Hate Machine era. Definitively a NIN song that its going to become a classic, specially the loud chorus \\"Do you f*cking know what you are?\\" that are carried along a distortion and a very effective keyboard. AWESOME. <br /> <br />3.- The Collector - A very irregular song. But its not a bad song at all. The initial beat reminds me of the Downward Spiral era, the choruses are a weird combination between NIN and... Sonic Youth with Smashing Pumpkins. All those points sound great but they don't quite finish getting around together but don't disappoint either. <br /> <br />4.- The Hand that feeds - The best NIN industrial-pop song ever. Very danceable, very effective. \\"Will you bite the hands that feeds you? Will you stay down on your knees?\\" asks Reznor. <br /> <br />5.- Love is not enough - Another odd song. Trent surely did a lot of experimentations with his own sound. Unfortunately this song its forgettable. Not bad, but not good. This is the song to skip in the album. <br /> <br />6.- Everyday is exactly the same - AWESOME! One of the best songs in the album. A very moody song that starts with a great synth background. The choruses, while a little repetitive, get along with the song smoothly. The song finishes with a great range of musical layers. <br /> <br />7.- With teeth - The title song is also the oddest one. A great tune overall. It starts with a classical NIN beat that suddenly \\"crashes\\" into a piano interlude that explodes again suddenly into a heavy industrial closure. <br /> <br />8.- Only - At first I tho' this song was goingto suck. But it developed into a very experimental and original song. Executed in spoken word with an 80's-ish beat. The choruses \\"There is no you, there is only me\\" Are very danceable. This song made me want to be in a bar. Reminds me about Talking Heads. <br /> <br />9.- Getting Smaller. Straight to the point rock that reminds of Queen of the Stone Age but better. The guitar work in this song it's very catchy and effective. <br /> <br />10.- Sunspots - A great beat that reminds a lot the Downward Spiral days. Again a very nice synth work. <br /> <br />11.- The line begins to blur - A difficult song, but after few listens it has grown on me. Great tune. <br /> <br />12.- Besides you in time - Another weird song. It develops VERY SLOWLY, at first it seems like Trent singing over a loop, but then it explodes into a very nice guitar + synth solo, great song. It feels epic. The end it's AWESOME. <br /> <br />13.- Right where it belongs - Years ago Hurt was for me one of the best melancholic songs in music history. Then Trent released Still that had a little song called \\"And all that could have been\\" that replaced Hurt in my musical world. Now, in this album, Trent give us this little tune that don't tops \\"And all that could have been\\" but its still a lot better than Hurt. A very simplistic Piano tune with Trent singing. In the middle of the song Trent's voice becomes clearer and you can just feel the real power of this tune. Excellent closer. Also, its one of the best lyrics by Reznor to date. I felt chills in my spine the first time I heard the line \\"if you look at your reflection, is that all you want to be?\\" <br /> <br />Overall, and awesome, odd, experimental, different album. It feel lighter, but not commercial, it feels like NIN, but at the same time it doesn't. I still need to listen it a few times. But right now I'm giving this album a 9.5/10 and you know how picky I am about music. Too bad about \\"Love is not enough\\". One of the most boring NIN songs made surrounded by great tunes.
B000929AJQ|5.0|I became a NIN fan two years after The Fragile was released.  This means I had to patiently wait 4 years in order to hear a new NIN record.  The wait, I will admit was tough, but the end result made it worth it.  With Teeth is a very unique and original step for Trent to take.  The production is probably the most amazing thing about the CD.   <br /> <br />It is raw and stripped back.  He is able to create an industrial sound by using guitars, real drums, bass, etc. as the main focus instead of sythns, drum machines and computers.  I find this amazing.  There is a lot of subtle effects being created by these instruments to create this overall sound.  Granted it is still a NIN so there are a good deal of programmed stuff, but it is not as apparent as it is on the last few NIN CDs.  <br /> <br />Now for the overall musical direction of the CD.  Trent decided to focus more on the vocals and lyrics than anything else on the CD, and it shows.  The vocals are stronger than ever.  He even brings back some motifs throughout the album with his vocal lines.  The songs this time around are a lot simpler than other releases.  Most of them are verse/chorus based making it easier to absorb on the surface.  Even though the music is fairly simple the big picture is still complex and will not make sense after the first listen.  The music direction is really dirverse and varied throughout the CD.  It has some real moody pieces such as \\"All the Love in the World\\", \\"Beside you in Time\\" and \\"Right Where it Belongs\\" that sound like they could have come from The Fragile.  When I say it sounds like it could have been on The Fragile I don't mean that it sounds like anything off of the Fragile it just sounds like it fits in with that style.  The CD also contains songs like \\"You know What you are?\\" and \\"Getting Smaller\\" which could be argued to be some of the heaviest and most aggressive material that Trent has done in some time.  Lastly, the CD contains a lot of groovey straight ahead rockerslike \\"The Collector\\", \\"The Hand that Feeds\\", \\"Sunspots\\" and \\"Only\\".  This CD has everything for a fan of Trent and NIN.  If you have liked everything NIN has done to this point there is no doubt that you will dig it.   <br /> <br />Like most NIN CDs it takes time to get into and understand what Trent is trying to do.  If the CD doesn't grab you after the first listen don't worry because it will probably take some time to grow.  I would also recomend this CD for people who aren't too familiar with NIN because it is more live band oriented and it has a good balance of stuff they have accomplished to this point.  This CD was worth the wait and it sounds like a CD that will sound even better live.  To clear one thing up, if you are looking for a Pretty Hate Machine, Broken, Downward Spiral, or The Fragile 2 you will most likely be turned off.  Eventhough I make comparisons to other albums it doesn't mean it sounds like them.  With Teeth is a completely original approach to the ever evolving sound of NIN.

B0007CNXUK|5.0|Rarely does a film portray real life without maudlin sadness or giddy saccharine dialogue. \\"Finding Neverland\\" is just what the titles suggests - a `neverland'. J.M. Barrie (a splendidly underplayed Johnny Depp) is a man that escapes his unsatisfying married life by fantasy (he is a playwright). Helping him create his best play happens when he befriends four boys who's Mother is the widow Sylvia Llewelyn Davies (an adorable Kate Winslet). To complicate matters, Sylvia's Mother (Julie Christy at her coldest role yet), intervenes suggesting that a grown man should not be interested in young boys and Sylvia should not be interested in a married man. The friendships develop with a turn of face by every character by the stories end. Freddie Highmore plays a young boy who steals every scene he is in. This is a light-hearted story threatening to be undermined by the stuffy British society who is viewed as the `evil adult world'. Slight scenes of fantasy are cleverly interspersed throughout the film and the epiphany that each character captures is brilliantly scripted. Peter Pan never looked so good.
B000929AJQ|5.0|I had a preconceived notion this was going to be a 4 star album.  \\"The Hand That Feeds\\" was really growing on me through consistant radio play, but it was still no \\"Closer\\" and Trent Reznor promised WITH TEETH would be a more accessable(commercial) album.  I had confidence it wouldn't be a terrible album, just not one I would repeat over and over until it wouldn't play anymore like previous NIN efforts. Times, music and myself have all changed since the 90's. \\"All The Love In The World\\" opens the album with a down tempo track that's not one of the best NIN slow songs I've heard.  But then \\"You Know What You Are?\\" comes in with Dave Grohl hammering the drums and it only gets better as the album progresses.  I always liked NIN using drum machines in large part as an alternative to live drums to fit their sound, but the live drums (especially with Dave) are a perfect progression for them and essential for making this a great album.  The CD is full of distorted disco/funk grooves trading out with melancholy piano riffs that are classic NIN.  After listening and listening again I think WITH TEETH is exactly what it should be, not rehash DOWNWARD SPIRAL or THE FRAGILE but still very distinct NIN worth playing over and over again.    P.S. Serious lovers of rock/metal and even other genres of music owe it to themselves to check out Fair To Midland.  Go to their website at [...]

B00001ZWTT|5.0|Why does everyone hate this movie so much? Not that my two cents matters any, but I think this is an action/comedy/Western that surpasses films like Star Wars and Count Of Monte Cristo in swashbuckling entertainment value. Will Smith plays Jim West, a gunslinging, black-cowboy-hat-wearing action hero. Kevin Kline plays Artemus Gordon, the inventor and government agent who teams up with Smith's character to stop a madman bent on destroying the United States! Packed with explosive action, comedy, and great special effects, Wild Wild West is a fun, entertaining popcorn movie that you will love!

B0007YMUZW|5.0|First, to get something off my chest just because it's tarnishing my enjoyment of this CD:<br /><br />Most Ryan Adams reviews can be divided into two camps: those who deride him as an egomaniacal poseur and those who herald him as a genius.  We toss about \\"our generation's Dylan\\" for any twenty-something singer/songwriter (e.g. Conor Oberst), until they gain too much success; then we label them a sell out and complain that they mimic all the great bands we once compared them to. It's become as trendy to hate Ryan Adams as it is to like him. So, enough with ragging on him because he acts like a rock star and please, for the love of god, stop comparing him to Dylan.  He's fantastic, but there will never be another Dylan and you only set yourself up for derision when you make that comparison.<br /><br />Critiques of his music often center on one of three points: 1) he's \\"copying\\" off of other (presumably better) musicians; 2) there are many other more \\"innovative\\" artists out there (followed by a list of said artists); and 3) his lyrics are trite/full of cliches.<br /><br />My response to those critics is:<br /><br />1) since when did emulating the sound of other artists (particularly those that we like) become some sort of sin?  I appreciate the fact that Ryan Adams' albums have a touch of the \\"Byrds and Tom Petty\\" (to quote another review for this album).  According to these critics, music is supposed to be life-changing and, when it happens to influence another musician, they are supposed to forget the influence music has had on them.  I don't get it.<br /><br />2) \\"Innovation\\" is highly overrated (e.g. the Fiery Furnaces).  I didn't anticipate the release of Cold Roses wondering what magic Adams was going to create using only a Fisher Price xylophone and a hubcap.  And seriously, how much innovation can we really have?  We're reaching a critical moment wherein everything's been said and every note has been matched up with every other note and the only way to be \\"innovative\\" will be to be nonsensical and out of tune (e.g. the Fiery Furnaces). (That being said, I do like Rilo Kiley and the Decemberists, although I would argue that there's a distinction to be made between \\"original\\" and \\"innovative\\", or at least in the way they are bandied about by music critics.)<br /><br />3) I don't look to lyrics for some sort of life-affirmation or lesson.  It's nice if it happens, but it's not something I demand of a CD. Occasionally, something happens in my life and I happen to listen to a particular song and the song clicks with me.  Sometimes it just makes good driving music.  If every song was filled with huge, heavy lyrics, all I would do is sit in my car and cry.  As appealing as that sounds, I have things to do and places to go.  And I will be listening to Cold Roses as I go about my merry way.<br /><br />Sorry for the rant, but now on to the review:<br /><br />After Rock N Roll (which I hated), I was concerned that he'd fallen over his own ego.  Whether or not he's the monster people make him out to be, the new album is great.  The Cardinals are a fantastic band, as spectacular on the album as they are live.  I would agree with the reviewer who said the album's a mix of Pneumonia and Heartbreaker.  If you liked either of those albums, you'll probably like this one.  I haven't listened to it enough to say it's my favorite, but it is full of great tunes.  If I was forced to put three songs on repeat for the rest of the day, I'd pick \\"When Will You Come Back Home\\", \\"Easy Plateau\\" and \\"Dance All Night.\\"  I've omitted \\"Let It Ride\\" only because I've already listened to it 1,000 times in the last few weeks.<br /><br />Listen to it.  If you like it, buy it.  If not, buy something else.  There's hardly any excuse these days to accidentally buy something that you think sucks.y to be \\"innovative\\" will be to be nonsensical and out of tune (e.g. the Fiery Furnaces). (That being said, I do like Rilo Kiley and the Decemberists, although I would argue that there's a distinction to be made between \\"original\\" and \\"innovative\\", or at least in the way they are bandied about by music critics.) <br /> <br />3) I don't look to lyrics for some sort of life-affirmation or lesson.  It's nice if it happens, but it's not something I demand of a CD. Occasionally, something happens in my life and I happen to listen to a particular song and the song clicks with me.  Sometimes it just makes good driving music.  If every song was filled with huge, heavy lyrics, all I would do is sit in my car and cry.  As appealing as that sounds, I have things to do and places to go.  And I will be listening to Cold Roses as I go about my merry way. <br /> <br />Sorry for the rant, but now on to the review: <br /> <br />After Rock N Roll (which I hated), I was concerned that he'd fallen over his own ego.  Whether or not he's the monster people make him out to be, the new album is great.  The Cardinals are a fantastic band, as spectacular on the album as they are live.  I would agree with the reviewer who said the album's a mix of Pneumonia and Heartbreaker.  If you liked either of those albums, you'll probably like this one. B000001EYW|4.0|The Bee Gees albums are typicall known for containing 2 elements: lush ballads and funky, uptempo numbers.  While the lush ballads have always been a personal favorite, the Brothers Gibb have also recorded some great dance/pop songs like: \\"Jive Talkin'\\", \\"Nights on Broadway\\", \\"You Should be Dancing\\", \\"Stayin' Alive\\", \\"Night Fever\\", \\"Tragedy\\", \\"Love You Inside Out\\", \\"He's a Liar\\", \\"The Woman in You\\", \\"You Win Again\\", \\"One\\", and \\"Paying the Price of Love\\". <br /> <br />This CD however lacks any of the percussive beats that have driven some of the Bee Gees best tunes.  The closest the brothers get to anything resembling a beat are the hit single \\"Alone\\", the follow-up \\"Still Waters Run Deep\\", and album cuts \\"With my Eyes Closed\\" and \\"Smoke and Mirrors\\". All of the songs are sung in the whispered, hushed voices that they used on classic songs like \\"How Deep is Your Love\\" and \\"How Can You Mend a Broken Heart\\".   <br /> <br />Besides the 2 singles, some of the other good cuts include \\"Miracles Happen\\", \\"Smoke and Mirrors\\", \\"I Surrender\\", \\"My Lovers Prayer\\", and \\"Closer Than Close\\".  My only problem with this CD is that there is nothing here to get you up on your feet and dance.  Sure, \\"Alone\\" is a great song to sing along to in the car, but there is nothing really fun and energetic about these tracks. <br /> <br />If you like the melodic, lush ballad side of the Bee Gees, then you will enjoy this CD.  If you like the funky, dance side of the Bee Gees, there is not much here for you.  However, I still recommend this CD for some great Bee Gees melodies.
B000929AJQ|2.0|Six years on since the release of \\"The Fragile\\", its followup, \\"With Teeth\\", finally arrived.  After the experimental \\"The Fragile\\", Reznor took a few less chances this time around and produced an album that is song-oriented.  The drawback to this is that the record is a lot less risk taking, and while some of the material is great, most of it lacks an edge to me.  Now mind you, I approach this from a different context than most folks, my interest musically tends to be in change-- if an artist stands still and produces something very similar to a previous record, I rarely am interested in it (something about revisiting old ideas to me results in a lack of urgency and edge to the music).  Truth to be told, if you though \\"The Fragile\\" was weak because it lacked many of the hooks of the earlier albums, you'll probably love this one. <br /> <br />Over the past sixteen years, Reznor has really created a vocabulary built of pop sensibilities meets industrial, and we see a bunch of songs that could have easily been lifted from earlier records-- the sort of merciless industrial of \\"Broken\\" (\\"You Know What You Are?\\", \\"Getting Smaller\\"), the thrashy synth pop sounds of \\"Pretty Hate Machine\\" (\\"Every Day Is Exactly the Same\\", \\"Love is Not Enough\\"), the sludgy industrial rhythms and dark pop of \\"The Downward Spiral\\" (\\"The Line Begins to Blur\\", \\"Right Where It Belongs\\").  Truth is, this album sounds more like a successor to those than it does to \\"The Fragile\\".  There's also a couple downright irritating moments (the chorus to \\"With Teeth\\" and the endless panning to the otherwise decent \\"Beside You in Time\\"). <br /> <br />But intermingled throughout this is hints at a new sound, a sort of funk sensibility that begins to creep into Reznor's music-- opener \\"All the Love In the World\\" illustrates this well, with its voice over bass and drum, but its really the incredible \\"Sunspots\\" that is totally unique and best illustrates this-- it has no precedent in Reznor's music and works well, musically and lyrically. <br /> <br />Overall, I found the album pretty much a disappointment because of its lack of freshness is direction.  I've heard it before.

B00005JNQ8|4.0|What is it about 2005s The Interpreter, directed by Sydney Pollack and starring Nicole Kidman and Sean Penn that has sent audiences around the globe into a not so eloquent verbal and critical frenzy?  Its semi predictable ending perhaps?  Honestly, I don't think Sydney Pollack was out to shock the masses with a twisted and unexpected ending, or even to make a film rife with explosions and action sequences.  It's deeper than that, and thank god.  If there's one director to make a political thriller, it's Pollack, just take a look at 2003s The Quiet American, in all its haunting and heartbreaking glory.   Maybe if the hundreds of eyes in the theatre actually looked into the film rather than skimmed its surface, they might be able to comprehend its incredibly accurate and important message, particularly in our lives today.  If this were the case, then maybe the ending would still be up in the air, leaving you breathless, maybe a little shocked to have seen the incredible lengths that people will go to in order to defend their culture, their lifestyles, their lives.  How appropriate this theme is in a time of unsettled American and international conflict. (Spoiler alert). Sure, maybe you figured out that Nicole Kidman took the job as a U.N interpreter in search of the opportunity to get close to the man who gave her and her country everything and then stripped it away, an opportunity to carry out her vengeance, (and if that's the case, bravo to you), but beneath that is her incredibly powerful performance, supported by a witty, wry and exceptionally well written screenplay by Martin Stellman and Brian Ward.  Admittedly, Sean Penn and Nicole Kidman are an unexpected duo, but the energy they both exude (particularly Kidman) lights up the screen in performances equally worthy of praise.  It's an electrifying film, one that will pierce deep into your core if you let it, and leave you thinking about so much more than whether or not Nicole Kidman's accent was accurate. (By the way, the African languages were fictional, made up for the film, so that excuse bears no merit here on whether or not this film is worth seeing.) Cheers, folks.

B000002U6E|2.0|When Michel Cretu launched his enigmatic Enigma project in 1990 the group were literally in a class by themselves. Numerous soundalike acts cropped up during the 3 year wait bewteen debut and follow-up albums with only one single from the motion picture \\"Sliver\\" to hold fans over. The wait really raised expectations for something truly phenomenal which may be part of the reason why I count this album as the weakest of Enigma's first 4 studio albums.<br /><br />The album opens strongly with \\"Second Chapter\\" as the familiar horn opening welcomes us back to the world of Enigma and the music suddenly changes and becomes darker before flowing into the \\"The eyes of truth.\\"  \\"The eyes of truth\\" is to me the stand out track on this album but it is also the one that sounds most like the work done on MCMXC ad. With its heavy orchestral sample from Anne Dudley's \\"Songs from the Victorious city\\" and mix of Eastern/ Indian sound it is truly a  amazing if not ominous sounding tracks.<br /><br />The album then segues into the worlwide hit \\"return to innoncence\\" which features lots of Enigma's signature sounds combined with Taiwanese chanting. The video clip to this song helped propel it to the tops of many music charts with its images of everything going backwards.<br /><br />The album from this point starts to get a bit choppy. \\"i love you..I'll kill you\\" while a fan favorite reminds me of many Enigma clone acts who made music that could have fit into any low budget B-movie's soft porn scene. It does have some interesting beats but the Lyrics just seem at times ridiculous.<br /><br />\\"Silent Warrior\\" begins and with the sound of farwaway crickets and soft music getting louder. Musically the track wonderful with heavy percussion and some nice keyboard work and tribal samples. Here again the lyrics didnt work for me and neither did Michel Cretu's vocals which are at times strained if not distracting.<br /><br />We are next treated to \\"dream of the dolphin\\" a short peaceful piano based track with some vocals by Sandra that soon fades into a reworked verions of \\"carly's song\\" called \\"Age of Loneliness.\\" Thsi track features more of the overtly sexual themes that were present on the act's first album along with heavy female breathing and chugging dance rhythms.<br /><br />A psychedelic guitar and voices singing bring the listener into \\"out of the deep.\\" Initially I was horrified by this track when I first heard it as it reminded me of re-interpretation of The beatles' \\"Lucy in the sky with diamonds\\" but on further listenings the song works. Cretu again takes lead vocals but they work here as the song has a \\"rockier\\" sound than \\"silent warrior.\\" The video clip is one of Enigma's best featuring a knight who goes to an abandoned underwater castle and the painting's come to life. I am still baffled as to why this clip was left off their greatest hits DVD.<br /><br />Finally the album closes with \\"cross of changes\\" which features a few spoken lines by Sandra before closing out in the true Enigma fashion with the horn closing.<br /><br />\\"Cross of Changes\\" overall isnt a very cohesive album compared to MCMXC ad. In retrospect I think Cretu was experimenting with the Enigma sound diversify it which hurts the album overall. Not a terrible album but In my opinion definetly the weakest of the first four studio albums.ful piano based track with some vocals by Sandra that soon fades into a reworked verions of \\"carly's song\\" called \\"Age of Loneliness.\\" Thsi track features more of the overtly sexual themes that were present on the act's first album along with heavy female breathing and chugging dance rhythms. <br /> <br />A psychedelic guitar and voices singing bring the listener into \\"out of the deep.\\" Initially I was horrified by this track when I first heard it as it reminded me of re-interpretation of The beatles' \\"Lucy in the sky with diamonds\\" but on further listenings the song works. B00000K3D4|5.0|Nearly twenty years complete with a computer-effects \\"revolution\\" in film have passed since Jim Henson's Labyrinth hit theatres, but no visual advancements could ever capture the charisma of this pop rock fairy tale. Henson's Creature Shop not only designed a spectacular fantasy world born from the depths of every child's imagination, they put it together completely with practical effects and the magic of puppetry.  If you're looking for the pleasantly simple shapes and colors of The Muppets, you won't find them here; Labyrinth's puppets blend seamlessly into the background in order to make this universe spring to life. <br /> <br />The story begins in a charming East Coast-esque neighborhood park where a teenage girl dressed in a ball room gown performs a soliloquy to no audience other than her dog.  The town clock chimes and it begins to pour; Sarah (Academy Award-winner Jennifer Connelly as a teen) pulls out of her reverie, a princess no more, and realizes that she has stayed out too long. At home, she confronts her \\"wicked\\" stepmother who has been waiting for Sarah to return in order to watch her new baby brother, Toby, while her father and stepmother spend the night out. Although it's never stated, it's clear from the way in which Sarah admires the portrait of her mother on her bedroom mirror that her mother, an actress in a play called The Labyrinth, has passed away and that is the reason that Sarah loves the play with such devotion. The way in which she derides her half-brother, angry that he has played with one of her own childhood stuffed animals and annoyed with his fits of crying, demonstrates very quickly the tension between the newly formed family and Sarah's resistance to the life that she has had to face since her mother's death. When Sarah repeats the lines of her favorite play, calling forth a \\"Goblin King\\" to kidnap Toby and free her of his annoyances, she doesn't imagine that her own improvised echo of \\"I wish that the goblins would come and takeyou away... right now,\\" would in fact be magic words that bring forth a Goblin King, Jareth (British rock star David Bowie). Jareth takes Toby and offers Sarah a life of fantasy, liberated from harsh reality. But Sarah, feeling guilty, asks for Toby back instead; however, Jareth refuses, and in order to free Toby from Jareth's control, Sarah must make her way through the trials of a mystical labyrinth within thirteen hours. <br /> <br />Sarah's choice to face the labyrinth and the lessons she learns thanks to the friends she meets along the way help the introverted teen to mature and realize that even when surrounded by a life of the fantastic, she can never escape completely from reality.  This basic journey mirrors the mythic quest archetype of many legends and stories, but the change in the expected protagonist to that of a young girl and the mix of contemporary and fantasy settings offers something to the genre that hasn't quite been seen before or since. Bowie composed most of the songs in the film, which range from the fun and effervescent \\"Dance Magic Dance\\" to his character's poignant take on unrequited love in \\"As the World Falls Down\\" and \\"Within You.\\" The title track (\\"Underground\\") especially will stay with you, even long after you've last watched the film.

I have only one complaint, they used the \\"F\\" word about a hundred times and that ruined the movie for me. Even Dick Winters himself complained about that in his book. Other than that the movie was excellent.
B00003CWPL|5.0|One thing that everyone who has seen Eraserhead will agree upon is that it certainly isn't for everyone. However, those who are bold enough to watch this confusing, slow, and uncomfortable film will be treated to one of the most memorable (and disturbing) movies ever made. Go into this one with an open mind, and don't spend too much time trying to figure out its ultimate meaning. Watch it alone in the dark for the ultimate experience.<br /><br />The remastered DVD offered at David Lynch's website is wonderful, if a bit on the expensive side. My advice is to save up for the box set that also includes David Lynch's short films. That way you'll have a good weekend worth of bizarre film entertainment that you'll never forget!

B00005ASHM|5.0|I understand why some people don't like \\"Pet Sounds.\\"  It's kind of the \\"Citizen Kane\\" of albums.  People hear the rep -- that this is one of the greatest records ever -- and they put it on expecting the direct propulsive creativity of, say, something like \\"Sgt. Pepper\\" or \\"Good Vibrations.\\"  And what they get is something milder, something innocent, something strangely muted.  Then when it's over they think, \\"THAT'S one of the greatest albums ever???\\"     To an extent, I was one of those people.  I got \\"Pet Sounds\\" when it first hit CD, when I was just about 20, and I'd heard all the hype and I definitely liked it... but at the time I also felt I wanted something more, something that grabbed me by the collar and shook me.      But this is not an album that will shake you, at least not violently. An old girlfriend of mine once came into my house while I was listening to this and actually got angry at it: \\"This is lullaby music, this is like Sesame Street. Why are you listening to this?\\"     I couldn't explain it to her anymore than I could explain it to myself but this is an album that almost has to grow on you.  The more you listen, the more you learn, the more you live, the better it gets.      There is a clutch of albums that I have a tendency to drag out on dark nights of the soul -- Nick Drake's \\"Five Leaves Left,\\" \\"Beatles for Sale,\\" John Coltrane's \\"Soultrane,\\" \\"Thelonious Monk Plays Duke Ellington,\\" \\"Astral Weeks,\\" \\"Dark Side of the Moon,\\" \\"Imperial Bedroom,\\" \\"The Band\\" and a few others.  But this is the one I put on when I just want to sit alone and stare out the window or drive around dark, snowy neighborhoods at night.    Anyway, I would never tell anyone, \\"Like this album or you are WRONG!\\"  But for people who think it's a sham, I'd recommend they listen to some key moments and reflect on what they're hearing:    ** The bells and harmonies of \\"You Still Believe In Me,\\" and particularly the line, \\"I wanna cry,\\" in which the word cry is given something like 15 lilting syllables.      ** The cellos of \\"Don't Talk\\" and \\"I'm Waiting for the Day,\\" particularly the strings that kick in at the 2:21 mark (followed by rumbling kettle drums that would make Phil Spector tremble).    ** All of \\"God Only Knows.\\"    ** The flickering texture of the bass guitar in \\"Here Today.\\"    ** The closing refrain of \\"I Just Wasn't Made for These Times.\\"    ** The weird, kitschy sound of the title track.    ** Brian's truly beautiful lead vocal on \\"Caroline, No,\\" followed by train sounds and vocals by his dogs, Banana and Louie -- maybe the greatest, saddest, most wistful ending of any album ever made.

B0000WN0ZK|5.0|Blow-up is a wonderful film, filled with images of swinging 60s London. The story is engrossing: a photographer inadvertently captures a crime on film while following a couple in a park. He gradually becomes immersed in a series of bizarre events beginning with a visit from the subject of his filmic foray. When he develops the negatives and blows them up, an entirely hidden reality unravels before his eyes.<br /><br />Apart from all of the above reasons to see this cinema classic, there is another recommendation. There is a brief scene where the photographer (David Hemmings) goes into a London rock and roll club. The band onstage? None other than the legendary Yardbirds...at the peak of their creativity! Even more fascinating is the fact that this was filmed during the period when the band featured two immortal lead guitar icons: Jeff Beck AND Jimmy Page! The brevity of this sequence is sad, but the few moments of wild guitar interplay is worth the price of the DVD. Especially when you can view the Yardbirds segment over and over without damaging the disc. (Try this with the VHS!) A classic rock and roll snapshot from the glory years.

B00006AW2J|5.0|After a year or so of psychedelic hooha, the Dirty London Five returned to their blues roots with this record. Brian, disenchanted with the boys a bit, plays a bit less here, especially since he was all over Their Satanic Majesties Request. Obviously, his days with them are numbered. The album is a big turning point in their career. The early blues days of 12x5 and Now! are gone. They ahve their own sound now, rather than much of the same as The Yardbirds and such, playing the black man's blues without much of their own originality. They play the blues THEIR way here. And they do a damn fine job. Of all their records, I'd say this is their crowing achievement. <br />Good Stuff: <br />Sympathy For The Devil: Samba rhythm, crazy Keef Rick guitar, and Satanic Mick. Whoa! This is one dark song. The lyrics are great. By the way: the devil is mankind in the story. <br />Street Fighting Man: ROCK AND ROLL! Actually, the bass is the only electric instrument, everything else is just heaily distorted acoustic stuff! But Charlie pounds away and Brian evens throws in some sitar amongst the acoustic napal,. How cool is that? <br />Stray Cat Blues: Little girls and hard guitars. Okay! <br />Factory Girl: A folk number that somehow channels English working class as well as drunken Americans. And it has some fiddle and groovy percussion. Classic unsober Mick also. <br />The Salt Of The Earth: An ode to the \\"hard workin' people,\\" those lower class men and women who live the simp;e life. Chalrie drums loud, Mick sings his heart out and everything just soudns great. Soul choir comes in the add extra flavor and it all ends with an upward speed change that would be repeated in \\"You Can't Alway Get What You Want.\\" Possibly their best song.

0195170776|5.0|This is a review of the second edition of the dictionary.  Naturally, it has been revised substantially by adding or updating entries and usage notes.  This is well described by the publisher and other reviews. <br /> <br />A key new feature called \\"The Right Word\\" are valuable synonym study boxes discussing subtle differences in meaning, e.g., \\"definite\\" vs. \\"definitive\\". <br /> <br />The typography has been completely overhauled.  The change is definitely for the better, although this may sound surprising given the richness and complexity in the first edition.  Word functions, usage levels, examples, etc., are again set in distinct fonts, yet they harmonize here much better than before.  I especially like the new italic face frequently seen in the numerous and illuminating examples.  Phrases are explicitly set off from the main entry yet at equal weight.  Etymologies and derivatives follow tightly at the very end but are still clearly recognizable. <br /> <br />The appendix has also received some attention and is now much more appropriate for a dictionary.  The various \\"Hall of Fame\\" lists from the first edition have rightly been dropped in favor of informative and relevant language aids covering grammar, style, spelling, capitalization and punctuation.  This part also includes several interesting lists of commonly mis-spelled words, clichs to avoid, and redundant expressions. <br /> <br />This is the best desk dictionary of contemporary American English.

This is the story of how they got through it and the things that happened to them on the way there and back again. <br /> <br />It brings to life the multiplicity of different type people who made up the crews. They came from different backgrounds and places. They get hacked off with each other. They also pull together when the time comes for them to do so. <br /> <br />Forget the cliches. Get this one to remind you about the Greatest Generation!

B000929AJQ|5.0|First of all, this is an incredible album...the creativity that Trent has in creating an album is not lacking in this one. Although somewhat different than we're used to, the entire album is a welcome distraction from the music being produced today. But is this a tell-all look into Trent's soul? Listen to the lyrics and you'll see that the majority of the album has Trent revealing the emptiness of his mind, and the loss of control over himself. Anyone who has listened to Pink Floyd in the Syd Barrett days can attest to a parallel between this album and Syd's writings before he lost complete control. Will this be Trent's final album? Will he soon be forever lost within his own mind? Only time will tell. Buy the album.
6305537321|4.0|Breakfast at Tiffany's is the story of a wandering eccentric called Holly Golightly whose actions slowly lead her to the man she loves.<br /><br />Holly is a strange one. She calms herself from the \\"mean reds,\\" different than the blues, by breakfasting at Tiffany's, the jewelry store. She is frequently given $50 by rich men to go to the powder room and although they're terrible bores, Holly consistently surrounds herself with them. She makes her living by visiting an ex-mobster in Sing Sing and giving him the weather report. She grew up as Loula Mae on a farm with her brother Fred who she loves dearly. When she escaped, she came to New York to lead her eccentric life with her feline alter ego she simply calls \\"cat\\" so that they do not belong to each other.<br /><br />The character of Holly is a composite of many personalities of the era including the tempestuous Marilyn Monroe.<br /><br />Paul Varjak is a writer/gigolo who slowly falls in love with Holly. He is straight forward, quite the opposite of Holly who randomly enters his room in the night for a short visit and calls him Fred after her brother.<br /><br />The cat is used as a symbol of Holly's true self. She often accepts and rejects the cat in the film during appropriate times during her life.<br /><br />The song Moon River is used throughout the film highly effectively. Audrey Hepburn sings the song beautifully and illustrates a melancholy mood that hovers over the film.<br /><br />The one fault of the movie is the slow pace. Because of Holly's flightiness, the story progresses with jolts and sputters. It truly follows her life and not necessarily one looming important event as many movies do.<br /><br />Overall, it is an excellent film with an exceptional cast.
B0001906O0|5.0|Robert Smith has expressed his appreciation for well conceived B-Sides.  He has said that he respects bands whose catalogue of B-Sides offer a rare glimpse, a different side, that is just as incredible as the A-side songs.  I could not agree with Robert Smith more.  B-Sides from respectable musicians are never the left over, mediocre \\"filler\\" songs that didn't make it on an album - they are a necessary shadow to a given album.    When you hear the B-Sides that The Cure produced, it is apparent that Robert Smith took his B-Side work very seriously.  If you had been a Cure fan and not heard the majority of B-Sides before, it was once acceptable, considering it once took some effort to get hold of most - but now, with the release of Join the Dots, there is no longer an excuse.  Having these B-Sides is crucial to rounding out any collection of the Cure's music, to get a complete and accurate portrayal of their incredible legacy.      Analogy time:  If the Cure's music were a movie, not having the B-Sides would be like watching 3/4 of the movie screen.  Some of the very best moments take place on that 1/4 of the screen that you are missing.      These B-Sides are that crucial.  If you are a cure fan and have not heard them, go get this box set and step through the looking glass.  Although there will be some songs that dont make the grade, you will gain a whole new appreciation.  Enjoy.
